review.title: Opinion Polarity Identification through Adjectives
review.abstract: "What other people think" has always been an important piece of information during various decision-making processes. Today people frequently make their opinions available via the Internet, and as a result, the Web has become an excellent source for gathering consumer opinions. There are now numerous Web resources containing such opinions, e.g., product reviews forums, discussion groups, and Blogs. But, due to the large amount of information and the wide range of sources, it is essentially impossible for a customer to read all of the reviews and make an informed decision on whether to purchase the product. It is also difficult for the manufacturer or seller of a product to accurately monitor customer opinions. For this reason, mining customer reviews, or opinion mining, has become an important issue for research in Web information extraction. One of the important topics in this research area is the identification of opinion polarity. The opinion polarity of a review is usually expressed with values 'positive', 'negative' or 'neutral'. We propose a technique for identifying polarity of reviews by identifying the polarity of the adjectives that appear in them. Our evaluation shows the technique can provide accuracy in the area of 73%, which is well above the 58%-64% provided by naive Bayesian classifiers.

metadata.title: Opinion Polarity Identification through Adjectives

sections.text: "What other people think" has always been an important source of information during various decision-making processes. Today, people often share their opinions on the Internet, and as a result, the Web has become an excellent source for collecting consumer opinions. There are now numerous web resources that contain such opinions, such as product review forums, discussion groups and blogs. However, due to the abundance of information and the wide range of sources, it is essentially impossible for a customer to read all the reviews and make an informed decision about purchasing the product. It is also difficult for the manufacturer or seller of a product to closely monitor customer opinions. Therefore, mining customer reviews or opinion polls have become an important topic for web information extraction research. One of the important topics in this area of research is the identification of opinion polarity. The opinion polarity of a review is usually expressed with values of "positive," "negative" or "neutral." We propose a technique for identifying polarity by identifying the polarity in the adjectives.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The Web has significantly changed the way consumers express their opinions. Product reviews exist today in a variety of forms on the Web; however, lately, reading a representative selection of product reviews to make a good decision has often been a time-consuming process. It is also difficult for the manufacturer or seller of a product to use the reviews. Recently, there has been interest in the development and use of mining and summary tools specifically to determine opinion polarity [1]. The polarity of a word or opinion, also called semantic orientation, indicates the direction in which the word or opinion for its semantic group deviates from the norm. In other words, the polarity of words or phrases directly reflects the opinion of the writer. Polarity usually extends across an ordinary (i.e. discrete) scale. This scale can take the form of either an ordered set of numerical values (e.g. one to five "stars") or an ordered set of numerical algorithms.

sections.heading: 2. PROPOSED TECHNIQUE
sections.text: In the next step, our algorithm calculates the polarity of each adjective based on a learned classifier. By aggregating the polarity of the adjectives of opinion (based on their frequency), the polarity of opinion is identified. To determine the polarity of an adjective, we use a naive Bayesian classifier, learned through a series of positive, negative and neutral adjectives. Input of this classifier consists of a tuple of values showing the similarity between the given adjective and the three fixed adjectives "excellent," "mediocre" and "poor" as representatives of positive, neutral and negative adjectives. These similarity values are calculated based on two suggested similarity functions based on WordNet [3]. The first similarity function is based on the synonyms of the adjectives and the second is based on an explanation for the function of these adjectives and the following on the similarity of the individual adjectives.

sections.heading: 2.3 POLARITY IDENTIFICATION
sections.text: The final phase of our technique involves determining the polarity of opinion. Polarity is determined by aggregating the polarity of the extracted adjectives based on their frequency. In other words, our method assigns the values of + 1, 0 and -1 to the positive, neutral and negative adjectives for each check. Each adjective also receives a weight corresponding to its frequency in this check. Polarity of the check is then determined by calculating the weighted average of the adjective values. We consider two methods, the first, SynPI, based on SynClassifier, and the second, StemPI, based on StemClassifier.Table 8 shows the accuracy, false-positive and false-negative percentages of the two polarity identification methods SynPI and StemPI. Since the test set was selected at random, the results may vary in different rounds.

sections.heading: 3. EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the accuracy of our proposed opinion polarity classifier, SynPI, by comparing it to a baseline classifier method (presented in Chapter 6 of the NLTK [4]). The baseline classifier method is based on a naive Bayesian classifier learned with a series of tagged ratings. To evaluate our system, we use a series of ratings available via movie _ reviews in nltk.corpus [4]. These ratings have been categorized into "positive" and "negative" classes. Our evaluation technique involves randomly selecting a set of 100 ratings, which are then made available to our system for polarity predictions. This baseline method first finds the most common words in the training set, and then uses them to learn the naive Bayean classifier. Each feature of this classifier shows that the review contains a specific word.

sections.heading: 4. RELATED WORK
sections.text: One class consists of works that aim exclusively at determining effective metrics to represent the polarity and subjective content of words [5]; the other class consists of works that perform word polarity as part of a larger study of opinion classifications and related areas [6]. Our work is in the second class, so we focus on opinion classification in our related work environment. Turney in [1] introduces an unattended learning algorithm to rate an assessment as positive or negative (thumbs up or down); the algorithm extracts phrases that contain adjectives or adjectives, and also their parts of speech (POS) tags match the predefined patterns. This paper also suggests a method of using "PMI-IR" for the semantic orientation of phrases.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The algorithm consists of three phases: (1) extraction of adjectives and their frequency from the given review, (2) prediction of the polarity of each adjective using the learned classifier, and (3) classification of the review based on the weighted average polarity of the adjectives. The core of the technique is the second phase that WordNet uses to calculate similarity values between two adjectives, and then uses the similarity values to learn the classifier to predict the polarity of each adjective.In experiments with 100 reviews from the movie _ reviews corpus in NLTK, our algorithm achieves an accuracy of 73%, while the basic method can at best achieve an accuracy of 64%. The great advantage of our method is that it can achieve a high accuracy with a small training set.In addition, our proposed opinion polarity classifier is independent of the context and can be achieved with the other type of classification that we can fully apply.
